data.text: The benefit of dedicated touring bikes is its convenience factor when addressing problems that could occur when you're out in the boonies. If you can work around those conveniences and actively engage in pre-emptive risk management then any bike will take you the distance, including this one. But if you're only gonna be doing touring outside of small daily rides, and it seems like you have a decent budget, might as well get an actual touring bike.
data.author: Kelvin Bungcayao

data.text: I have the road version with 105 gearing. I put a more compact front chainset on 46 big 36 small and kept the standard 11/30 back. It‚Äôs very capable and comfortable (with a Brooks saddle) and can carry a lot thanks to front pannier mounts on the carbon forks as well as rear mounts.
data.author: Gregory W Nicholas

data.text: I saw some guys bikepacking on the rc500 and rc520 in Britanny so yes you could tour if you're fairly light. I have an rc500 but I wouldn't tour on it because the wheels aren't particularly strong IMO. I broke 2 spokes on my Triban and that wasn't carrying panniers
data.author: Gary Sheridan

data.text: It would be a good idea to explain what your touring plans are. If it is cycling from Switserland to Tibet, I would advice to look for another bike that is realy labeled as a 'Touring bike'. This one is a basic gravel bike. But you can upgrade it to be a 'touring bike'. So where do you want to ride, for how long, what distances...?
data.author: Walter van Tienen

data.text: Gravel bikes make good touring bikes, provided you can fit a rack (which that bike can)
data.author: William Nel-Barker

data.text: Consider the Riverside touring 520 and 900. Both specifically made for touring by Decathlon. Here's my 520 (blue bike) presently a third of the way to Grenoble from Nottingham.
data.author: Richard Maher

data.text: The RC120 frame is a robust one. I had the non-gravel version and I loved it.
data.author: Alan Phoenix-Bates

data.text: It will work but you will need to change the gearing unless you are just going to ride in flat country. With an 11-40 cassette at the back, a 32 tooth chainring would be better than the 38 tooth it comes with, for climbing hills with a load. Most gravel bikes are set up for riding fast without carrying any luggage and most people will need a lower bottom gear for touring or bikepacking.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: I use a 2019 scott speedster, 105/grx mix. Full mudguards, rack, 32 tyres and guards. 22 speed, 11-36 rear, 46-30 front, plenty of gears, no problems with wheels when touring and I'm no lightweight
data.author: Alan Norris
